Award.AwardTitle: Learning Applied Science and Effective Research (LASER)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Texas Lutheran University (TLU) has received an NSF Scholarships for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) award for their project entitled "Learning Applied Science and Effective Research (LASER)." LASER will increase the number of academically talented and financially needy students and graduates in biology, biochemistry, chemistry, and physics. The project team will recruit and enroll 16 students to form two LASER cohorts: eight students in year one and eight students in year two. Students will be retained through graduation, achieving a baccalaureate degree, and employed in a STEM career within six months of graduation.

A well-planned retention program will build on TLU academic support services that include supplemental instruction, peer tutoring, and strong career development programs. New STEM support services being designed specifically for LASER include a LASER living/learning community, cohorted courses, LASER peer and faculty mentors, professional networking, cohorted co-curricular STEM career modules, and science internship/research opportunities. The project external evaluator will use both formative and summative evaluations to assess student progress to degree, participation in project activities, graduation rates, and career placement. Particular emphasis will be placed on the surveys to assess and improve the co-curricular career modules and professional conferences/networking. These data will provide information about effective support of students through to graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our S-STEM grant was titled Learning Applied Science and Effective Research (LASER). We envisioned a program of two cohorts who would form ties and retain in the sciences (focused on Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Computer Science and Physics). We would support the students with funding to meet their unfunded need.

Of the hastily assembled 1st cohort of eight, two stayed eligible and graduated from TLU, one dropped below our 3.0 GPA limit but still retained as a math major and graduated from TLU, and five transferred away from TLU (most had a low GPA prior to transferring). This led to looking for replacement students in the same class who looked as though they might maintain a 3.0.

Year 2, fall 2016, we were able, with some negotiation, to arrange a Living Learning community with five LASER students and two STEM students who had no unmet need, but wanted the LLC experience. Five out of the seven retained at TLU, and four graduated in STEM, although only one was supported all four years. The others either changed majors (one graduated in Psychology) or dropped below the 3.0 GPA.

In 2017 and going forward, we tried to support as many students as possible, replacing those who changed majors, left TLU, or could not keep up the GPA.

In retrospect, we set our GPA requirement too high, at a 3.0. We initially had a one-semester grace period but petitioned and received a change to two semesters. We required the students to do a co-curricular module in the spring, which went well. It was a constant challenge to find replacements for students who left the program (or TLU totally).

We presented a poster dealing with our NSF instructional grants (the S-STEM LASER grant and an IUSE grant) at the 2019 Microbe meeting (ASM) in San Francisco, and I attended the fall 2019 S-STEM meeting in Washington DC.

Student comments from annual evaluations by Dr. Boehm, our external assessor, follow:

Impact of the S-STEM scholarship

-I probably would have had to work a lot more hours at an actual job as opposed to being able to focus more on my academics because the [program] helped pay for it.

-We are getting scholarships for having good grades, so I feel like it?s really pushing me more to excel.

Benefits of LASER program participation

            -I was part of the group that when to the Texas Academy of Sciences meeting in Belton. If it wasn't for it being paid for, I would not have gone. Being there really helped me see what students are researching and what being a scientist entails. Because I am in the LASER program, I am able to do summer research with Dr. Jonas. If I wasn't in the LASER program, I don't think I would have reached out to him, because he's the one reached out and asked if I want to do this. 1st year LASER student

            -Before [LASER] I really had no idea what I wanted to do, but after, I realized there are specific fields that I am really interested in. I found specific jobs at specific companies like NASA, Apple, Samsung. The LASER program has opened the doors. 1st year LASER student

Benefits of Living-Learning Community

            -They [peers] understand the course load, because we all have a ton of homework and we all     have hard classes. As freshmen, we?re still adjusting to college, so it's good to have someone there who knows what we?re going through. 1st year LASER student

            -If you?re in the sciences, you don't really have time for a lot of social activities, so it was awesome to already have a set of people I knew to socialize with. 1st year LASER student

Effect of module upon perceptions of career options

            -I felt like that speaker showed us that with a science major, you could go to a business career   and still have a science career. It showed us that with this education, there is a wide variety of things we could do. 1st year LASER student

In conclusion, our LASER program provided needed financial assistance to several STEM students. They retained in STEM to a greater extent, regardless of their ability to maintain the scholarship. Being able to take students to professional STEM meetings was influential; many students remarked on their meeting experiences being important in opening their eyes to possibilities. Many students had unmet need exceeding the $10,000 maximum, which led to a mistake on our part where we had to repay NSF for overpayment of students. We could have supported many good Biology majors except that their goal was medical school or another health-related program. The performance of the LASER students, based upon retention and GPA data, suggests that the financial investment in these students is both wise and productive.
